The '''2002 FIFA World Cup Final''' was a [[Association football|football]] match that took place on 30 June 2002 at the [[International Stadium Yokohama|International Stadium]] in [[Yokohama]] to determine the winner of the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]]. The final was contested by [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]]. It was the first World Cup meeting between the two sides. Brazil won the match 2–0, winning a record fifth title. [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]], who became the record World Cup goalscorer at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 tournament]], scored two of his fifteen World Cup goals in the second half of the match, leading Brazil to the title and winning the [[World Cup Golden Boot|Golden Boot]] award. It also marked Brazilian captain [[Cafu]]'s third consecutive appearance in a World Cup Final, a feat that has yet to be accomplished by any other player in the history of the tournament. Both teams had won their respective groups before advancing to the [[2002 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|knockout stage]], where Germany shut out all of their opponents to reach the final, while Brazil only allowed a single goal from [[England national football team|England]]. Germany overcame [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] and co-host [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]], while Brazil knocked out England and Turkey.

The title marked Brazil's fifth World Cup championship, which is more than any other nation has achieved, also being the first team to win all seven of their games without any extra time or penalty kicks. Brazil also became the first nation to win the World Cup outside Europe and the Americas. Germany lost the World Cup Final for its fourth time, another tournament record. They were attempting to equal Brazil for most World Cup wins, as they already had three.

As of [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]] this was the last World Cup final that ended in regulation time. It is also the most recent World Cup won by a South American team.

===Germany===
{{further|2002 FIFA World Cup Group E}}
Prior to the tournament, Germany were plagued by a series of injuries to key players. [[Sebastian Deisler]], a star player, would not be able to play in the tournament due to a knee injury suffered in a friendly match against [[Austria national football team|Austria]], only two days before the team left for Japan. The team's medical staff was at first confident that Deisler would be able to play, but later pulled him out due to fears of his safety.<ref name="injuries">{{cite news|title=Germany's Deisler ruled out of Cup|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/world/2002/world_cup/news/2002/05/20/germany_deisler_rb/|accessdate=25 June 2010|newspaper=Sports Illustrated|date=20 May 2002}}</ref> "At first we had a glimmer of hope, but now the most important thing to think about is the health of Sebastian rather than the World Cup," said team manager [[Rudi Völler]].<ref name="injuries"/> In addition, midfielder [[Mehmet Scholl]] and defenders [[Christian Wörns]] and [[Jens Nowotny]] all missed the tournament due to injury.<ref name="injuries"/>

Germany was drawn into Group E, along with [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and the low-ranking [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] and [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]].<ref name="main-fifa">{{cite web|title=2002 FIFA World Cup Korea/Japan: Results |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/index.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=25 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021164417/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/index.html |archivedate=21 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> In their opening match at the [[Sapporo Dome]] against Saudi Arabia they showed dominance, defeating them 8–0. [[Miroslav Klose]] scored a [[hat-trick]], one of six different players on the German team to score a goal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Germany – Saudi Arabia |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950004/report.html |publisher=FIFA |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615212854/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950004/report.html |archivedate=2010-06-15 |df= }}</ref> In their next game against Ireland, Germany held a 1–0 lead throughout much of the game. However, with only a few seconds left in [[stoppage time]], Irish player [[Robbie Keane]], scored the equalising goal against German goalkeeper [[Oliver Kahn]].<ref name="nz">{{cite news|title=Soccer: Keane saves Ireland with last-gasp goal against Germany|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=2045202|accessdate=25 June 2010|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|date=6 June 2010}}</ref> The goal held and the match ended in a 1–1 draw, awarding Germany only one point in the standings.<ref name="nz"/> Needing a win to finish first in their group, Germany entered their final match against Cameroon one point ahead of the Irish in the group. However, Germany easily beat Cameroon in a 2–0 game at [[Shizuoka Stadium]], with Klose scoring his fifth goal of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cameroon – Germany |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950035/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=25 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615212901/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950035/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> Germany finished first place in Group E with seven points (two wins and a draw), and advanced into the first stage of the knockout round.<ref name="main-fifa"/>

In the first stage of the knockout round, Germany faced [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]], the runner-up in Group B, at [[Jeju World Cup Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Germany – Paraguay |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950049/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=25 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615212947/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950049/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> The game remained a very defensive one, as there were no goals scored in the first half and well into the second half. In the 88th minute, first-time, [[Oliver Neuville]] scored, winning the game for Germany.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news|title=Germany edge out Paraguay|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/matches_wallchart/germany_v_paraguay/default.stm|accessdate=10 April 2011|work=BBC|date=15 June 2002}}</ref> In the quarter-finals, Germany faced [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]], who had surprisingly made it far into the tournament. Although they were significantly outshot 11 to 6, the Germans were still able to pull away with a 1–0 win. The single goal scored in the match came from [[Michael Ballack]] in the 38th minute.<ref>{{cite web|title=Germany – USA |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950058/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=25 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615213008/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950058/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref>

In the semi-final, Germany faced the co-host nation South Korea at the [[Seoul World Cup Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Germany - Korea Republic |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950061/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=26 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615213015/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950061/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> Like the game against Paraguay, it was a defensive struggle throughout the first half and into the second half. However, before any goals were scored, a key moment in the tournament occurred. In the 71st minute, Ballack picked up his second yellow card of the knockout round, therefore disqualifying him from the next game.<ref name="korea">{{cite news|last=Hughes|first=Rob|title=Germany shatters Korea's dream|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/26/news/26iht-soccer_ed3__20.html|accessdate=26 June 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|date=26 June 2002}}</ref> However, just four minutes later into the game, Ballack came through for Germany and scored, which turned out to be the only goal of the game. With the 1–0 win, the Germans moved into the final to face Brazil, the first World Cup meeting between the two.<ref name="korea"/>

===Brazil===
{{further|2002 FIFA World Cup Group C}}
Brazil was drawn into Group C, along with [[China national football team|China PR]], [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]], and [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]].<ref name="main-fifa"/> In the previous World Cup in 1998, Brazil had made it to the finals but then lost 3–0 to the host nation [[France national football team|France]].<ref name="si-brazil">{{cite news|title=Brazil World Cup Preview|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/world/2002/world_cup/news/2002/05/27/ws_previews/|accessdate=26 June 2010|newspaper=Sports Illustrated|date=27 May 2002}}</ref> In an interview, Brazilian midfielder [[Juninho Paulista]] stated that both the team and the people in Brazil were both somewhat pessimistic about the upcoming World Cup squad due to the loss to France.<ref name="si-brazil"/> Following the 1998 loss, the team hired a new head coach, [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]], following tenures by [[Vanderlei Luxemburgo]] (whose contract was terminated after elimination at the quarter finals of the [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|football tournament]] at the [[2000 Summer Olympics]]) and [[Emerson Leão]] (who experienced a short, disastrous stint, in which the underpowered Brazilian team risked not getting through the qualifiers).<ref name="brazil2">{{cite news|title=Brazilian bullies have eyes on prize|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/world/2002/world_cup/news/2002/05/30/groupc_preview_sa/|accessdate=26 June 2010|newspaper=Sports Illustrated|date=31 May 2002}}</ref> Felipe preferred a more different style of football than previous coaches, which he called "bullyboy soccer". In this style of play emphasis is placed on aggressive play and hard tackling, which was in contrast to the more finesse play of previous Brazilian teams.<ref name="brazil2"/>

On June 3, Brazil played its first match of the group stage against eventual group runner-up Turkey. In stoppage time at the end of the first half, Turkey's [[Hasan Şaş]] scored, leaving Brazil down 1–0 at half time.<ref name="brazil3">{{cite web|title=Brazil – Turkey |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950010/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=26 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615212820/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950010/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> In the second half, Brazil's Ronaldo responded quickly by levelling the scores at 1–1 in the 50th minute. The score remained tied until well late into the game. In the 86th minute, Turkish defender [[Alpay Özalan]] brought down Brazilian striker [[Luiz Bombonato Goulart|Luizão]] in the penalty area, prompting a red card for Alpay and a penalty kick that Rivaldo converted.<ref name="brazil3"/> The match score finished at 2–1, Brazil victorious.<ref name="brazil3"/> The game was also notable for an incident, where Turkish defender [[Hakan Ünsal]] kicked a ball towards Rivaldo which struck his thigh, but Rivaldo fell to the ground clutching his face. The referee sent the Turkish player off with a second yellow card, while Rivaldo was fined 11,670 [[Swiss franc]]s by FIFA following a video review.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/jun/04/worldcupfootball2002.sport16 Scolari: Rivaldo did not cheat] ''[[The Guardian]]'' 4 June 2002</ref> In their second game against China at [[Ulsan Munsu Football Stadium]], the Brazilians fared much more easily. [[Roberto Carlos (footballer)|Roberto Carlos]], [[Rivaldo]], [[Ronaldinho]], and [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] all scored for Brazil, the first three goals being in the first half.<ref name="brazil4">{{cite web|title=Brazil – China PR |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950026/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=26 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615212825/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950026/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> With this win, Brazil also knocked the Chinese team out of the World Cup with their second loss.<ref name="brazil4"/> In their final game against Costa Rica, Brazil was very strong offensively. In a 5–2 win, Ronaldo scored two goals, one of four Brazilian players to score in the match.<ref>{{cite web|title=Costa Rica – Brazil |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950041/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=26 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615212830/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950041/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> Brazil finished in first place in their group with nine points and scoring eleven goals, advancing to the round of 16 with ease.<ref name="main-fifa"/>

Entering the elimination round with a perfect record, Brazil faced Group H runner-up Belgium in the first stage.<ref name="main-fifa"/> The game remained scoreless at half time, as both teams had good goalkeeping. In the 67th minute, striker Rivaldo scored for Brazil. Ronaldo added on a second goal in the 87th minute, solidifying the win for Brazil at 2–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=43950200/match=43950054/index.html |title=Brazil - Belgium |publisher=FIFA|accessdate=26 June 2010|year=2002}}</ref> England faced Brazil in the quarterfinals, and got ahead early with a goal by forward [[Michael Owen]] in the 23rd minute.<ref name="brazil6">{{cite web|title=England – Brazil |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950057/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=26 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516165756/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950057/report.html |archivedate=16 May 2010 |df= }}</ref> The scores were levelled in the first half's stoppage time, when Rivaldo scored in his second straight match just before the half was called.<ref name="brazil6"/> Following half time, forward [[Ronaldinho]] scored for Brazil, putting them in the lead. Only seven minutes later, Ronaldinho was red-carded by referee [[Felipe Ramos Rizo]] of Mexico and therefore suspended for the next match.<ref name="brazil6"/> Although they played with only 10 men, the Brazilians were able to prevent a second goal from their English opponents and advanced into the semi-finals to face Turkey.<ref name="main-fifa"/>

In the semi-final, the sans-Ronaldinho Brazil faced Turkey for the second time, at [[Saitama Stadium]]. The game, unlike the first meeting between the teams, had a strong showing of defense by both sides.<ref name="brazil7">{{cite web|title=Brazil – Turkey |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=4395/results/matches/match=43950062/report.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=27 June 2010 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615213017/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D4395/results/matches/match%3D43950062/report.html |archivedate=15 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> The game was a scoreless tie at half-time, but this soon changed. Only four minutes after the half in the 49th minute, Ronaldo again came through for Brazil, scoring what ended up being the only goal of the match.<ref name="brazil7"/> With this low-scoring victory, the Brazilians moved on to attempt to win a record fifth World Cup title, against the aforementioned German squad.<ref name="main-fifa"/>

==Background==
===Broadcasting and venue===
Over 200 different nations and territories broadcast the final over [[radio]] and [[television]].<ref name="tv">{{cite web|title=FIFA World Cup & Television |url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/fifafacts/ffprojects/ip-401_06e_tv_2658.pdf |work=InfoPlus |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=27 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614094554/http://www.fifa.com/mm/document/fifafacts/ffprojects/ip-401_06e_tv_2658.pdf |archivedate=14 June 2007 |df= }}</ref> In totality, 232 different television channels broadcast the match, which was a new record for a World Cup Final (only later to be broken in 2006).<ref name="tv"/> The final had the highest television audience of the entire tournament, attracting over 63 million viewers in [[Nielsen Media Research|Nielsen]]-measured countries.<ref name="tv2">{{cite web|title=Nielsen Media Research: Nearly 1.5 Billion TV Viewers Watch 2002 World Cup|url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-1906765/Nielsen-Media-Research-Nearly-1.html|publisher=Business Wire|accessdate=27 June 2010|date=30 July 2002}}</ref> The Germany-South Korea match was a close second, as much of the host nation viewed the game to support their team. It was the highest-viewed non-finals match in World Cup history.<ref name="tv2"/>

The game was played at [[International Stadium Yokohama]], where three other matches in the World Cup were previously held.<ref name="stadium">{{cite web|title=2002 FIFA World Cup "Stage of a Dream"|url=http://www.nissan-stadium.jp/english/index.php|publisher=Nissan Stadium|accessdate=27 June 2010|year=2002}}</ref> The stadium was the largest in the tournament as well as the largest in the entire nation of Japan, seating over 70,000 spectators.<ref name="stadium"/> In all, about 260,000 people attended matches in this stadium throughout the World Cup, which, at the time, was a new record.<ref name="stadium"/>

Despite being present, the [[Emperor of Japan]] [[Akihito]] did not join the ceremony of presenting the winners the World Cup trophy as it was against Japanese customs. Instead, FIFA President Sepp Blatter handed the trophy to Brazil captain [[Cafu]].<ref>[http://masdeporte.as.com/masdeporte/2002/06/29/polideportivo/1025324160_850215.html El emperador no se rebaja a dar el trofeo]</ref>

===Match ball===
{{further|Adidas Fevernova}}
The match ball for this game was the [[Adidas Fevernova]], a ball specifically made for the World Cup.<ref name="ball">{{cite web |title=Fevernova |url=http://www.soccerballworld.com/Fevernova.htm |publisher=SoccerBall World |accessdate=27 June 2010 |year=2003 }}</ref> The ball's design was different from the normal "Tango" type of three-pointed shapes connecting each hexagon, instead introducing a different, triangle-like shape on four hexagons.<ref name="ball"/> This look and color usage was entirely based on Asian culture. It also featured a refined syntactic foam layer, to give the ball superior performance characteristics, and a three-layer knitted chassis, allowing for a more precise and predictable flight path.<ref name="ball"/> However, this ball was notoriously criticised for being too light, yet some spectacular goals were scored with it during the tournament. The ball was also blamed for a number of upsets that happened in the knockout stages.<ref name="ball"/> Italian goalkeeper [[Gianluigi Buffon]] called the ball "a ridiculous kiddy's [[bouncing ball]]," while Brazil's [[Edilson]] criticised the ball as being "too big and too light".<ref name="ball"/>
